title: How to Reduce Data Usage on an Android Smartphone

steps.title: Limit your browsing to areas with Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Limit your browsing to areas with Wi-Fi. Whenever wireless Internet is available as an option, you should prioritize it over using data--even if your phone's data is faster than the Wi-Fi. Many public locations, such as coffee shops, have "free" Wi-Fi insofar as you must make a purchase in order to obtain the password.

steps.title: Stay off of social media when on data.
steps.content: Stay off of social media when on data. Using data-rich sites like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram while on data will quickly add up, especially since most of these services will load videos as you scroll through your feed.

steps.title: Use the mobile versions of sites.
steps.content: Use the mobile versions of sites. If you must browse while using data, avoid using sites' apps (e.g., YouTube or Facebook), and instead use the mobile site. You can typically access the mobile version of a site by typing "www.m.[sitename].com" into your Android's browser. For example, you would access the mobile version of Facebook by typing "www.m.facebook.com" into your Android's browser.

steps.title: Keep music and videos on your phone.
steps.content: Keep music and videos on your phone. Storing media such as music, photos, and videos locally rather than streaming them will save you hundreds of megabytes' (if not several gigabytes') worth of data.

steps.title: Avoid sending media-heavy text messages.
steps.content: Avoid sending media-heavy text messages. While texting over data generally constitutes a negligible amount of data use, sending large photos or videos will make a dent in your monthly data limit. The same goes for uploading photos or videos to Facebook, Instagram, and other social media.

steps.title: Use offline features in apps.
steps.content: Use offline features in apps. In Google Maps, for example, you can download a map of an area while connected to Wi-Fi and then use the offline map to navigate without using data. Offline use also applies to some cloud storage apps (e.g., OneDrive), YouTube Red subscribers, and Spotify Premium users.

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. This is a grey, gear-shaped app that you'll find in the App Drawer, which is the grid of dots at the bottom of the Home Screen.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Data usage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Data usage . It's typically beneath the "Wireless & Networks" heading. On Samsung Devices, first tap Connections at the top of the Settings menu, then tap Data usage . On some versions of Android you may first have to tap Wireless & Networks to see the Data usage option.

steps.title: Review your data usage.
steps.content: Review your data usage. You should see a date range (e.g., "10 January - 09 February") to the right of which is a number measured in either megabytes (MB) or gigabytes (GB). The number here is your data consumption over the last month. [1] X Research source You can also view the amount of data each app used during the specified date range by scrolling down.

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. This grey, gear-shaped app is typically found in the App Drawer.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Data usage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Data usage . It's under the "Wireless & Networks" heading. You may first have to tap Wireless & Networks on some Android phones.

steps.title: Tap Restrict background data.
steps.content: Tap Restrict background data . This option is near the bottom of the screen. [2] X Research source On some phones, you may instead have to tap Background data and then tap Off .

steps.title: Tap OK when prompted.
steps.content: Tap OK when prompted. Doing so will prevent any apps running in the background from using data, which will limit data use to the currently open app. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. It's a grey, gear-shaped app in the App Drawer.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Data usage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Data usage . This option is beneath the "Wireless & Networks" heading. You may first have to tap Wireless & Networks on some Android phones.

steps.title: Slide Set mobile data limit right to the "On" position.
steps.content: Slide Set mobile data limit right to the "On" position. Doing so will display a window with a black line and a red line on it. On some phones, you may instead have to tap Set mobile data limit and then tap On .

steps.title: Adjust the "Warning" and "Limit" lines.
steps.content: Adjust the "Warning" and "Limit" lines. To do so, tap and drag them up or down. The number left of the black "Warning" line pertains to the number of gigabytes of data you can use before your phone sends you an alert, while the red line dictates when your phone will disable your data for you. This feature is helpful for shutting off your data before you go over your monthly limit.

steps.title: Open Google Chrome.
steps.content: Open Google Chrome. This app is a red, yellow, green, and blue circle.

steps.title: Tap ⋮.
steps.content: Tap ⋮ . It's in the top-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . This option is near the bottom of the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Data Saver.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Data Saver . It's below the "Advanced" heading near the bottom of the menu. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Slide Data Saver right to the "On" position.
steps.content: Slide Data Saver right to the "On" position. Doing so will enable Chrome's Data Saver feature, which will compress website pages visited in Chrome in order to load them using less data.

steps.title: Open Google Play.
steps.content: Open Google Play. This is a white app with a multicolored triangle on it.

steps.title: Tap ☰.
steps.content: Tap ☰ . It's in the top-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . This option is in the pop-out menu on the left side of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Auto-update apps.
steps.content: Tap Auto-update apps . It's near the middle of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Auto-update apps over Wi-Fi only.
steps.content: Tap Auto-update apps over Wi-Fi only . This option is the bottom option on this page. Selecting it will prevent apps from auto-updating over data.

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. It's the grey, gear-shaped app in your Android's App Drawer.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Data usage.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Data usage . You'll usually find it beneath the "Wireless & Networks" heading. You may first have to tap Wireless & Networks to see the Data usage option.

steps.title: Slide Mobile data left to the "Off" position.
steps.content: Slide Mobile data left to the "Off" position. This slider is typically above or below the data window. Disabling data will prevent your Android from using data at all, which is useful if you're almost at the end of your data limit.
